key_channel_insights.line_content: BA.com pricing is now matched on 83% of OTA itineraries (+16 pp MoM), sharply reducing over-pricing risk.
60% of ODs are still cheaper on MSE—leakage easing but materially higher than other channels.
GDS fares price higher 89% of the time with a 17% average mark-up, exposing corporates to cost escalation.

conclusion.line_content: This report provides a high-level summary of the price discrepancies observed across different channels.  It is important to note that the data contains many nuances depending on various factors such as market conditions, booking windows, and the competitive landscape. Understanding these subtleties can be critical in optimizing pricing strategies and ensuring competitive positioning.

As part of our 'PriceEye' solution, we are developing an intuitive dashboard designed to help your airline's analysts drill down into this data. This tool will allow you to uncover and focus on critical actionable insights, enabling your team to make data-driven decisions with confidence.

We are here to support you in leveraging these insights to enhance your revenue management and distribution strategies. Please don't hesitate to connect with our team for more information about how PriceEye can assist you in achieving your business objectives.

ota_highlights.line_content: 82.6% of OTA fares now align with BA.com, up 6 pp WoW and 16 pp MoM—best YTD.
Short-haul and non-GB markets still show higher OTA prices on 14-18% of itineraries.
21+-day searches deliver 90% parity and just 6% OTA premiums after an 11 pp WoW drop.

ota_summary_high_level_comparison.line_content: Incidence down to 12.8% (-5 pp WoW) with a marginal +0.16% premium.
Only 2.6% of fares are lower on OTA, average ‑0.11% discount.

ota_summary_by_region.line_content: Parity 81.9% yet 14.4% OTA-higher share—largest concentration of gaps.
84.8% parity, OTA premiums limited to 7.5% at +0.05%.

ota_summary_by_point_of_origin.line_content: Parity 79.4%; OTA-higher cases 17.6% despite slightly lower +0.15% premium.

ota_summary_by_booking_window.line_content: Parity 78.5%; 16.2% OTA premiums persist for 0-20-day shoppers.

mse_highlights.line_content: MSE lists cheaper fares on 60% of ODs; higher pricing virtually absent.
Exact matches climbed to 40% (+12 pp WoW).
Average discount doubles on long haul (-0.11%), concentrating revenue risk.

mse_summary_high_level_comparison.line_content: Up 12 pp WoW, showing corrective progress.
Still majority, though frequency down 12 pp WoW; average gap ‑0.05%.

mse_summary_by_region.line_content: 63% cheaper on MSE (-0.04%); undercut share fell 14 pp WoW but remains high.
48% cheaper, 52% equal; deeper ‑0.11% discount increases revenue risk on premium routes.

mse_summary_by_point_of_origin.line_content: 73% of domestic ODs undercut (-0.06%), though improving 11 pp WoW.
Parity 57%; discount share 43% with similar magnitude (-0.05%).

mse_summary_by_booking_window.line_content: 52% cheaper, down 15 pp WoW; gap steady at ‑0.06%.
75% undercut for 22+-day searches (-0.05%), only minor progress.

gds_highlights.line_content: GDS priced higher on 89% of itineraries (+2 pp WoW); premium steady at 17%.
Higher-price share jumped 8 pp WoW to 68% for long haul.
For far-out bookings, 97% higher with a 21% premium—largest disparity.

gds_summary_by_region.line_content: 95.5% higher in GDS at +19%; virtually no parity.
67.5% higher (+7.5 pp WoW) but lower 11% premium; parity still 26.7%.

gds_summary_by_point_of_origin.line_content: 86.6% higher, 18% premium; incentive remains for direct channel.

gds_summary_by_booking_window.line_content: 96.7% higher (+2.6 pp WoW) with a 21% mark-up; parity nearly zero.
